items.claim: FLP Impossibility (1985): Deterministic consensus in asynchronous networks with crash faults is impossible
items.source: Fischer, M. J., Lynch, N. A., & Paterson, M. S. (1985). Impossibility of Distributed Consensus with One Faulty Process. Journal of the ACM, 32(2), 374-382.
items.interpretation: Determinism alone is insufficient; probabilistic (randomized) consensus required to break FLP impossibility. Thesis axiom DETERMINISM requires qualification.
items.formalStatement: ∃ asynchronous system with one faulty node → ∀ deterministic consensus protocol ∃ infinite execution. Must relax one property to achieve consensus.

items.claim: Bitcoin achieves practical safety with non-deterministic (probabilistic) finality: P(reversal) = (1/2)^n
items.source: Nakamoto, S. (2008). Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System. Original whitepaper.
items.interpretation: COUNTER-CLAIM: Non-deterministic system (probabilistic finality) achieves civilization-scale security. Contradicts thesis axiom requiring determinism for irreversible systems.
items.formalStatement: P(reversal after n confirmations) = (1/2)^n. For n=6: P(reversal) ≈ 1.56%, tolerable for economics but NOT formal safety guarantee.

items.claim: Probabilistic Byzantine Fault Tolerance (ProBFT): Achieves consensus with high probability at O(n√n) message complexity, 20% of PBFT
items.source: Avelãs, D., et al. (2024). Probabilistic Byzantine Fault Tolerance. PODC 2024 & ArXiv 2405.04606.
items.interpretation: COUNTER-CLAIM: Probabilistic consensus achieves better efficiency than deterministic with acceptable (not zero) failure probability. Challenges DETERMINISM necessity.
items.formalStatement: ProBFT: Message complexity O(n√n), safety/liveness guaranteed w.h.p. (with high probability). Deterministic PBFT: O(n²), deterministic safety.

items.claim: Bitcoin security is NOT purely probabilistic: economic incentives create de-facto determinism; 51% attack economically impossible, not mathematically impossible
items.source: Nakamoto, S. (2008). Bitcoin whitepaper. Game theory analysis: Böhme, R., et al. (2015). Bitcoin: Economics, Technology, and Governance. Journal of Economic Literature.
items.interpretation: COUNTER-COUNTER-CLAIM: Bitcoin achieves practical (not formal) determinism through economic design, not pure probability. Weakens falsification argument against determinism.
items.formalStatement: Bitcoin security: P(reversal) = (1/2)^n MATHEMATICALLY, but Cost(51% attack) >> Gain(reversal), so P_economic(attack) ≈ 0. Quasi-deterministic by incentive design.

items.claim: CANDIDATE FALSIFICATION: Quantum computing might break deterministic assumptions; quantum entropy is irreducible, limiting what determinism can achieve
items.source: Feynman, R. P. (1982). Simulating Physics with Computers. International Journal of Theoretical Physics.
items.interpretation: WEAK FALSIFICATION: If minimality requires quantum-compatible axioms, classical A = μ(O) calculus may be incomplete.
items.formalStatement: Quantum systems: state described by ψ; measurement yields probabilistic outcomes. No hidden variables can make quantum outcomes deterministic (Bell's theorem).

falsifications.summary: 5 strong counter-claim(s) found - thesis requires revision

SCALE.claim: Human working memory capacity is limited to 4±1 constructs, constraining decision throughput
SCALE.source: Miller, G. A. (1956). The magical number seven, plus or minus two: Some limits on our capacity for processing information. Psychological Review, 63(2), 81-97. Refined by Cowan, N. (2001). The magical number 4 in short-term memory.
SCALE.formalStatement: Working memory: 4±1 constructs, 5-9 bits of information, 30 second duration, process 3-5 pieces information

SCALE.claim: Decision quality degrades under cognitive load; humans cannot sustain review of >5000 decisions/hour
SCALE.source: PMC National Center for Biotechnology Information: Cognitive Load and Decision Fatigue research. Multiple peer-reviewed studies on decision quality degradation.
SCALE.formalStatement: Decision quality Q(load) is decreasing function of cognitive load L; Q'(L) < 0. Practical limit ~0.3-1.4 decisions/sec per human reviewer = ~1000-5000 decisions/hour

SCALE.claim: Decision bottleneck: Air traffic control system (ATC) cannot safely increase throughput beyond current limits without automation
SCALE.source: FAA Technical Report DOT/FAA/CT-TN23/5 (2023): Operational Throughput Analysis. Historical data: >50 years ATC operations.
SCALE.formalStatement: ATC throughput limit: 50-100 aircraft/sector, ~0.05-0.2 decisions/second. Attempts to exceed without automation → safety violations.

REVERSIBILITY.claim: Thermodynamic irreversibility is fundamental; entropy increases monotonically in irreversible processes
REVERSIBILITY.source: Ludwig Boltzmann (1875), Second Law of Thermodynamics. Modern formulation: Wikipedia Irreversible Process article.
REVERSIBILITY.formalStatement: dS/dt ≥ 0 for all real processes; equality only for reversible. For irreversible: ΔS > 0 always.

REVERSIBILITY.claim: Landauer's Principle: logical erasure of information requires thermodynamic irreversibility; one bit erased = kT ln(2) heat dissipation
REVERSIBILITY.source: Landauer, R. (1961). Irreversibility and Heat Generation in the Computing Process. IBM Journal. Referenced in PMC: Thermodynamical versus Logical Irreversibility.
REVERSIBILITY.formalStatement: Information loss (bit erasure) → ΔS_min = k_B ln(2) > 0. No post-hoc recovery without external input.

REVERSIBILITY.claim: First-error dominance in safety-critical systems: One uncaught error cascades to system failure; no post-hoc correction possible
REVERSIBILITY.source: Leveson, N. G. (2011). Engineering a Safer World. MIT Press. Chapter 4: Safety-Critical Systems.
REVERSIBILITY.formalStatement: Safety-critical: P(undetected error propagates) >> P(caught and corrected). First error dominates outcome.

DETERMINISM.claim: CAP Theorem (2000): Distributed systems can guarantee at most 2 of 3: Consistency, Availability, Partition-tolerance
DETERMINISM.source: Brewer, E. A. (2000). Towards Robust Distributed Systems. Formally proved: Gilbert, S. & Lynch, N. (2002). Brewer's Conjecture and the Feasibility of Consistent, Available, Partition-Tolerant Web Services.
DETERMINISM.formalStatement: ∀ distributed system with partition fault ∃ trade-off: either safety violated or liveness violated. At most 2 of {C, A, P}.

DETERMINISM.claim: Formal verification: Model checking can prove deterministic systems correct; probabilistic systems require statistical verification (weaker)
DETERMINISM.source: Clarke, E. M., Grumberg, O., & Peled, D. A. (1999). Model Checking. MIT Press. Chapter 3: Temporal Logic and Verification.
DETERMINISM.formalStatement: Deterministic systems: ∀ properties φ → verifiable in finite time. Probabilistic: ∃ probability δ > 0 that φ violated even with high confidence bounds.

DETERMINISM.claim: Raft consensus algorithm: Provides deterministic safety guarantees through election safety + log matching invariants (proven correct)
DETERMINISM.source: Ongaro, D., & Ousterhout, J. (2014). In Search of an Understandable Consensus Algorithm. USENIX ATC 2014.
DETERMINISM.formalStatement: Raft safety = Election Safety ∧ Log Matching ∧ Leader Completeness. Proven formally: no committed entries can be overwritten, ensuring deterministic safety.

COORDINATION.claim: CRDTs require commutativity and associativity: operations must commute (f∘g = g∘f) for eventual consistency
COORDINATION.source: Shapiro, M., et al. (2011). Conflict-free Replicated Data Types. INRIA RR-7687. Also: Wikipedia CRDT article.
COORDINATION.formalStatement: Strong eventual consistency ⟺ ∀ operations a,b: a∘b = b∘a (commutativity) ∧ (a∘b)∘c = a∘(b∘c) (associativity)

COORDINATION.claim: Event sourcing and distributed systems require idempotence: f(f(x)) = f(x) to survive message replay
COORDINATION.source: Cockroach Labs: Idempotency in Event-Driven Systems. Temporal: Idempotency and Durable Execution. Multiple industry patterns.
COORDINATION.formalStatement: Idempotence required: ∀ event e, ∀ n ∈ ℕ: apply(e) = apply(e,e,...,e) [n times]. Failure to enforce → data corruption on replay.

COORDINATION.claim: Merkle trees enable cryptographic verification of immutable data structures; hash chains provide deterministic proof of state
COORDINATION.source: Merkle, R. C. (1987). A Digital Signature Based on a Conventional Encryption Function. CRYPTO 1987 Proceedings.
COORDINATION.formalStatement: Merkle tree: hash(node) = H(hash(left) || hash(right)). Any mutation → different root. Verification O(log n), deterministic.

MINIMALITY.claim: Buckminster Fuller's Synergetics (1975): Geometric axioms based on 60-degree vectorial coordination
MINIMALITY.source: Fuller, R. B., & Loeb, A. L. (1975). Synergetics: Explorations in the Geometry of Thinking. Macmillan. ISBN 0-02-541870-X.
MINIMALITY.formalStatement: Fuller axiomatized geometry using tetrahedral/icosahedral symmetry (60° coordination) as minimal basis; claims sufficiency for universal description

MINIMALITY.claim: Fuller's Comprehensive Anticipatory Design Science (CADS): Formalized course structure (1950) before Synergetics publication (1975)
MINIMALITY.source: Buckminster Fuller Institute (BFI): Eight Strategies for Comprehensive Anticipatory Design Science. BFI Design Science Primer. Historical records.
MINIMALITY.formalStatement: CADS framework: anticipatory + deterministic + comprehensive design approach. Axioms unknown, but conceptually aligned with A = μ(O) projection calculus.

nextSteps: CRITICAL: Publish falsifications immediately and revise thesis
Fill axiom gaps: MINIMALITY: acquire 1 more evidence item(s)
Conduct peer review of evidence quality and scoring consistency
